did.unittitle: Jane Lathrop Stanford papers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The papers of Jane L. Stanford pertain largely to the founding and administration of Stanford University, along with her personal and social affairs; included in the papers are correspondence, business records, legal and financial papers, speeches, newsclippings, and biographical materials.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Jane Eliza Lathrop was born August 25, 1828, the daughter of Dyer Lathrop of Albany, New York. In 1850 she married Leland Stanford, returning with him to California in 1855 where they settled in Sacramento. Leland Stanford later became President of the Southern Pacific Railroad and Governor of California. Their only child, Leland Stanford, Jr., was born in 1868. During a European tour in 1884 he contracted typhoid fever and died in Florence, Italy. In 1885, Jane and Leland Stanford founded the Leland Stanford Junior University, in memory of their son. Jane was a full partner with her husband in the planning of the University, which opened in the fall of 1891. After her husband's death in 1893, she overcame great financial hardships to keep the University open until her husband's estate was settled. Thereafter, she directed expansion of the campus. She died on February 28, 1905 in Honolulu, Hawaii.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation:
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Jane Lathrop Stanford Papers (SC0033B). Dept. of Special Collections and University Archives, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, Calif.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: Gifts of Jane Lathrop Stanford, Thomas Welton Stanford, David Starr Jordan, Helen Stanford Canfield, David H. Canfield, and others; also includes purchases.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: Property rights reside with the repository. Literary rights reside with the creators of the documents or their heirs. To obtain permission to publish or reproduce, please contact the Public Services Librarian of the Dept. of Special Collections and University Archives.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research use.

did.unittitle: Correspondence

scopecontent.head: Series Description
scopecontent.p: Outgoing correspondence dates from 1860 to 1905 and incoming correspondence, from 1871 to 1905. Most of the correspondence concerns the University. Other topics include personal and social matters, her travels, religious discussions, and her interest in kindergartens. Correspondents include David Starr Jordan, the first president of Stanford University, Charles Lathrop, Susan B. Anthony, Timothy and May Hopkins, Julia D. Grant (Mrs. Ulysses Grant) and other members of the Grant family, Caroline Harrison (Mrs. Benjamin Harrison), and Andrew D. White. There are also a large number of condolence letters on the death of Leland Stanford and of begging letters.

did.unittitle: ALS to Dr. Jordan. Objects to his optimistic outlook on Judge Ross' decision.
ALS to Dr. Jordan. Thanks for congratulations.
ALS to Dr. Jordan. Receiving many letters of congratulations but dares not yet let her soul rejoice.
Telegram to Pres. D.S. Jordan. University exempt from inheritance tax.
ALS to Dr. Jordan. Pleased with Mr. Comstock's letter; uplifted by White's letter; later will give him these letters to be read by students when she is gone.
ALS [enclosure: letter by J.M. Stillman, June 21, 1895] to Pres. Jordan. Pleased at the evidence of Dr. Stillman's loyalty.
ALS to Dr. Jordan. Mrs. Biddle exercised about curios given to Museum.
ALS to Dr. Jordan. Passing on letter from George L. Burr.
ALS to Pres. Jordan. Wants a position for Mrs. Clement.

dao.title: Correspondence (outgoing) to David Starr Jordan, 1896 Jan-Aug

daodesc.p: Correspondence (outgoing) to David Starr Jordan, 1896 Jan-Aug: 1896

did.unittitle: Telegram to Dr. Jordan. Wants list of married and unmarried professors.
ALS to Dr. Jordan. Does not approve project to colonize Vina Ranch with colored people.
Telegram to Dr. Jordan. Suspend immediately religious professorships.
ALS to Dr. and Mrs. Jordan. Unite in silent prayer.
ALS to Dr. Jordan. Has invited Rev. Anna H. Shaw to preach in Chapel.
Telegram to David Jordan. Sincere thanks.
ALS to Dr. Jordan. Introducing Rev. C. S. Fackenthall.
ALS to Dr. Jordan. Regarding Mrs. Clements as mistress of Roble Hall.
ALS to Dr. Jordan. Wants Mr. Soule retained in his position.
ALS to Dr. Jordan. Does not like to be applied to for money; professors should not solicit from trustees.
ALS to Dr. Jordan. Encloses letter from Alex Hogg and response.
ALS to Dr. Jordan. Press must move Jan. 1; Quelle got married instead of paying his debts; has horror of debt.

dao.title: Correspondence (outgoing) to David Starr Jordan, 1896 Oct-Dec

daodesc.p: Correspondence (outgoing) to David Starr Jordan, 1896 Oct-Dec: 1896

did.unittitle: ALS to Dr. Jordan. Thankful he will remain at Stanford instead of going to Smithsonian Inst.; anxious about her brother Henry; has been asked to introduce Mrs. Chapman Catt.
ALS to Dr. Jordan. Sending copies of Valentine's book on money.
ALS to Dr. Jordan. Mr. Reed cannot accept.
ALS to Dr. Jordan. Thinks it is unwise to have fraternity in the Hall; Barber may give trouble.
ALS to Dr. Jordan. Thankful she has so true a helper; unable to make Swain vice-president now; wants to bring influence to bear on R.R. Co. to secure justice.
ALS to Pres. and Mrs. Jordan. Their return to Stanford University.
Telegram to Dr. Jordan. Does not like Prof. Miller approaching trustees for the money

dao.title: Correspondence (outgoing) to David Starr Jordan, 1897 Jan-Apr

daodesc.p: Correspondence (outgoing) to David Starr Jordan, 1897 Jan-Apr: 1897

did.unittitle: ALS to Dr. Jordan. Sending letter from Mrs. Clements; sorry that she had to put her in such a wretched position.
LS to Dr. Jordan. Correspondence to vindicate anything which might be said.
Telegram to Dr. Jordan. Wants Mrs. Clements address.
LS to Dr. Jordan. Objects to retention of Prof. Ross.
LS to Dr. Jordan. Acknowledges tickets to lectures at Golden Gate Hall.
LS to Dr. Jordan. Objects to recitation rooms in Encina Hall.
Telegram to Dr. Jordan. Has found a man for Palo Alto Communicate.
LS to Dr. Jordan. Wants Mr. Soule retained.
LS to Dr. Jordan. Only professors may build houses costing less than $4,000.00 on campus.
LS to Dr. Jordan. Prof. Stillman solely responsible for appointments of assistants; gave no encouragement to Mr. L. Booth.
ALS to Dr. Jordan. Objects to dancing in Encina Hall.
ALS to D. S. Jordan. Trip too dangerous for Dr. Jordan; his life too valuable for the future of Stanford University.

dao.title: Correspondence (outgoing) to David Starr Jordan, 1897 May-Nov

daodesc.p: Correspondence (outgoing) to David Starr Jordan, 1897 May-Nov: 1897

did.unittitle: ALS to Dr. Jordan. Transmitting address she had prepared to deliver on opening day.
Telegram to Dr. David Starr Jordan. Trip restful and pleasant; relieved of anxiety.
ALS to Dr. Jordan. Objects to proposal to realize on Market Street Railway stock for legatees; Met Mrs. Barnes in London.
ALS to Dr. Jordan. Anxious when he is away as no one can take his place; staying in New York to promote settlement of estate.
ALS to Dr. Jordan. Wants to see him for an hour; wants to know more of Mr. Hamlin; festival a success; Hildebrand dept wiped out.
ALS to Dr. David Starr Jordan. Status of Jennie S. Lathrop.
ALS to Dr. Jordan. Referring to correspondence by F. W. Hyde regarding drinking water on the Quad.
ALS to Dr. Jordan. Objects to the use of the Stanford name at a summer school in Pacific Grove [enclosed clippings].
LS to Dr. Jordan. Wants a recommendation for Grace Mathewson's music book.
ALS to Dr. Jordan. Glad he is safely home; is presently at Lisson's Tavern.
ALS to President Jordan. Prof. Elliot solely responsible for disbursement of fees.
ALS to Dr. Jordan. Holds Prof. Elliot in high esteem.
LS to Dr. Jordan. Regarding Sigma Nu matter.

LS. On academic freedom

LS. Wants a meeting of students and professors to pass resolutions for Judge Field
ALS. Refuses to lease land to outsiders.
LS. Thinks he should not be present at meeting of Trustees; every student has a soul germ in need of development

LS. Importance of soul development; example of Ingersoll; wants to establish a chair of ethics; Dr. Brown's position temorary
LS with typescript copy. Expansion of faculty must wait on building program

dao.title: Correspondence (outgoing) to David Starr Jordan, 1900 Jan-May 9

daodesc.p: Correspondence (outgoing) to David Starr Jordan, 1900 Jan-May 9: 1900

did.unittitle: LS. Thankful for his helpfulness; going to Los Angeles
N to Dr. and Mrs. Jordan. Invitation to reception.
LS. Consigns valuable letters to his care
LS. As well as ever; description of return home from trip; looking forward to Dr. Jordan's return.
N. Extends invitation to students to a reception [includes invitation of Apr. 20, 1900]
ALS. Wants Mr. Nash to go on a vacation

LS. Increase the income to $207,000.00 for the year; not wanting an increase to the number of students; Stanford stand ahead of all American Universities; development of soul the most essential thing in life; Stanford should aim to develop soul; Prof. Ross bringing tears to her eyes; Stanford not a political machine; Japanese immigration amount to serious proportions; Kearny incident

LS. Opinion remains the same.
TL. Wants boy's paper to have proper consideration
LS. Will get books for department most needing them; pleasure to see buildings go up in her lifetime; professors think they want many things they can do without
Tel. Secure Parliamentary papers at 1,500.
LS. Purchase of Parliamentary Papers authorized
LS. Thoughts on the Ross affair
Tel. approves act
Tel. declines to be further quoted in Ross affair
TLS. regarding the Ross affair; sympathy for losing Barbara
LS. could not have endured criticism in Ross affair without Divine support; disloyalty of Howard; expressed faith in Jordan's ability
LS. admires Branner's action in Ross affair; cautious about increasing payroll; advises limitation of students to focus on quality
LS. need to strengthen weak places in faculty; will allow increase in payroll
Tel. consents to payroll of $230,000
Tel. Take no action on salary question [original plus translation]
LS. refers payroll question to her brother [original plus typed copy]
LS. Ross affair of slight import if properly handled; no salary increases during building operations
LS. advises care in selection of professors; kept in N.Y. by physical disability
Typed extracts of letters re Chair of Christian Philosophy, salaries, limitation on students
ALS. her health; inviting graduates to dinner; will dedicate the church on Mar. 9
TLS. approves heroic action in case of Prof. Pease; her health; respect for Dr. Bull; dedication of church; description of alumni dinner
LS. payroll estimate granted; please that Prof. and Mrs. Smith are to return; public and students take the measure of professors
ALS. cannot consent to extra door to Library; thinks basement rooms should be utilized
ALS. introduction for Mrs. Stewart
ALS. affairs at Encina must end at midnight; dances limited to two per semester
LS. postpones decision on enlargement of clubhouse
LS. regarding planting Japanese cherry trees near his house
LS. regarding application of Emile Deschamps
LS. wants to send books to the University of Tokio [sic]
LS. surprised that space is filling up; likes Dr. Branner's spirit; fears "stone age" will not be over for sometime
LS. outside company not to have control of any campus building; intends to arrange for hospital off campus
LS. regarding four patients in Encina Hall
ALS. wants copy of report on salaries
ALS. transmitting invitation to students for a garden fete on Leland Jr.'s birthday
LS. going to send statement of entire amount of money spent on University
ALS. wants to read his proposed article on Ross affair
LS. concerning gift of his library
TLS. will continue hygiene dept. for two years
TLS. no student help to be employed
TLS. won't pay for items not ordered through business office
LS. will not consent to publication of his article on Ross affair
LS. enjoying stay in Ceylon; next month in India
PC from Darjeeling
PC from Port Said
TLS. not buying art at present
TLS. congratulations on birth of son
ALS. thoughts on Stillman tragedy; glad to hear Eric is doing well; her itinerary
LS. please with information about Dr. R. J. Campbell
LS. regrets calling of Prof. James without consultation; turned over all responsibility of the Educational Dept. to Board of Trustees [original and typed copy]
ALS. introducing Mrs. F. W. Richardson
ALS. regarding correspondence of Mr. Horace Davis which she did not see [original and 1 mss copy]
LS. deplores publicity in building operations; dislikes reference to "stone age"
L. enclosure sent to her by mistake

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Typescript copies of letters, primarily from J. L. Stanford to David Starr Jordan and primarily concerning the University; there is also an introductory essay on Jane L. Stanford by H. C. Nash, 1887. Also includes several excerpts from her journal of 1892 [which J. L. Stanford later destroyed].
